posts.name: I ask a whole lot of questions
posts.cooked: I was looking at old FMS stuff and came across this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sqd_Hk_fems Does anyone know what that blue box is for?
posts.display_username: I ask a whole lot of questions

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
I kinda miss that old thing, though it may just be nostalgia.

That box was hardware buttons for whats now done through the FMS UI on the screen.  It had match start/stop buttons, and one for each team that could bypass/estop teams.  The actual function of each button changed depending on what mode everything was in.

posts.name: I ask a whole lot of questions
posts.cooked: That’s cool wonder why they moved away from that? Thanks for helping me figure this out I could not find anything in the old whitepapers
posts.display_username: I ask a whole lot of questions

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Theyre little Linux sbcs which run driverstations also

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
That’s the FCUI ( FMS Field User Control Interface).

It was replaced by a GUI on the FMS server in 2014.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Peter Cooper Jr.
posts.cooked:
Gabe4:

That’s cool wonder why they moved away from that?

I think it was a combination of it being more expensive than it was worth to make a new custom hardware box for each new field, and it not being as useful in the 3v3 era since there were only 4 dedicated team-in-match buttons.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
I had forgotten that it only had the 4 “team” buttons…

You can see a better image of the controls side on slide 12 here: PPT - FRC Field Management System (FMS) Volunteer Position PowerPoint Presentation - ID:3634914

link_counts.title: PPT - FRC Field Management System (FMS) Volunteer Position PowerPoint Presentation - ID:3634914

posts.name: I ask a whole lot of questions
posts.cooked: Why did it have only 4? Didnt frc always use 3v3?
posts.display_username: I ask a whole lot of questions

posts.name: Micah
posts.cooked: The first 3v3 FRC game wasn’t until the 2005 game “Triple Play”. Most games before that were either 2v2 or had only 4 robots on the field at a time.
